articles.title: How Google Handles JavaScript In Its Indexing Process
articles.description: Once, if you wanted Google to index your content, it needed to be right in the HTML and not dynamically rendered with JavaScript. Things have changed, but how much? MERJ and Vercel analyzed over 100,000 Googlebot fetches in an attempt to empirically demystify Google‚Äôs approach.
articles.author: Zecchini, Moore, Siddle, Ubl (Vercel)

articles.title: Garbage Collection and Closures
articles.description: When three JavaScript experts get together and all learn something new about how JavaScript works when they encounter a memory leak, it pays to listen. An interesting quirk to be aware of.
articles.author: Jake Archibald

articles.title: Announcing TypeScript 5.6 Beta
articles.description: The first beta of the next major version of TypeScript is out. Region-prioritized diagnostics (VS Code only, for now) is a particularly interesting addition.
articles.author: Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft)

articles.title: Benchmarking AWS Lambda Cold Starts Across JS Runtimes
articles.description: It‚Äôs from the Deno team so it may not be surprising that Deno was fastest, but they share their methodology and results for Deno, Node, Bun and AWS‚Äôs managed Node runtime and they weren't all that far apart.
articles.author: Zinkovsky and Jiang (Deno)

articles.title: Node.js's Experimental Support for TypeScript
articles.description: In this pull request, Node merged an experimental ability to transpile TypeScript into JavaScript, ultimately letting Node directly ‚Äòrun TypeScript‚Äô. No type checking is performed and, as Matt Pocock explains, TypeScript-only features are a no-go.
articles.author: Sarah Gooding (Socket)

articles.title: A Different Way to Think About TypeScript
articles.description: ‚Äúa very expressive way to operate over sets, and using those sets to enforce strict compile time checks‚Äù
articles.author: Robby Pruzan

articles.title: emoji-picker-element: A Lightweight Emoji Picker
articles.description: An emoji picking control, packaged as a Web Component. You can also add custom emoji to it. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Nolan Lawson

articles.title: ‚òéÔ∏é¬†International Telephone Input
articles.description: A very mature option that offers all the trimmings you‚Äôd expect: accessibility, type definitions, flags, automatic country selection, automatic formatting, and more. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Jack O'Connor

articles.title: PythonMonkey: Embed a JavaScript Engine into the Python VM
articles.description: If you need to use Python but want to run JS, this gives you a way to do it with Mozilla‚Äôs SpiderMonkey engine. It now supports the CommonJS module system too.
articles.author: Distributive Corp.

articles.title: üìÖ¬†Calendar Link: Dynamically Generate Event Links for Calendars
articles.description: Generate event links for Google Calendar, Yahoo Calendar, Outlook, etc.
articles.author: Anand Chowdhary

articles.title: JS-PyTorch: A PyTorch-Like Library for JavaScript
articles.description: Recently renamed from JS-Torch, this brings some of the magic from Python‚Äôs popular PyTorch library to JavaScript for training and testing neural networks in particular. We linked to it earlier this year, but it has added GPU support thanks to GPU.js.
articles.author: Eduardo Leao

articles.title: json-to-csv-export: Generate Downloadable CSV of JSON Data
articles.description: You‚Äôve got some data in JSON, you want users to be able to download a CSV of that data.. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Coston Perkins

articles.description: Porffor is an experimental ahead-of-time JavaScript compiler/runtime that compiles to either WASM or native. Its developer has just gone full time on the project thanks to support from GitHub co-founder Chris Wanstrath.
React Conf 2024 has shared all the talks from its Las Vegas event back in May.
Ryan Dahl explains what Deno got wrong about HTTP imports and how it's moving forward.
Bun 1.1.21 ‚Äì The JavaScriptCore-based server-side JavaScript runtime improves its Node.js and Remix compatibility.
Node.js v20.16.0 (LTS)
ESLint v9.8.0

articles.title: Patterns for Memory Efficient DOM Manipulation
articles.description: Marc shares a solid look at the best practices to employ in order to avoid excess memory usage when managing/updating the DOM, all with a hope to make your apps faster. A good overview of the core principles behind DOM manipulation and optimization.
articles.author: Marc Grabanski

articles.title: üç™¬†'Third-Party Cookies Have Got to Go'
articles.description: Following Google‚Äôs recent about-turn on deprecating third-party cookies, the W3C reiterates their firm position, stating that these cross-site cookies ‚Äúare harmful to the web, and must be removed from the web platform‚Äù.
articles.author: Hadley Beeman (W3C)

articles.title: How the Paris 2024 Summer Olympics Has Impacted Internet¬†Traffic
articles.description: Admittedly not a frontend piece, but a timely and interesting post all the same on web traffic and the impact of major global events such as the Olympics.
articles.author: Tom√© and Pacheco (Cloudflare)

articles.title: User Location is a Lie
articles.description: Come for the nuance around location-based programming, stay for the list of potentially amusing place names. Beyond that, Austin dives into various ways to access user location, how these methods can sometimes fail, and what to do about it.
articles.author: Austin Gil

articles.title: Letter Spacing is Broken and There's Nothing We Can Do About It... Maybe
articles.description: ‚Äúa flaw so ingrained on the web that browsers have been ignoring the CSS specification for year‚Äù
articles.author: Juan Diego Rodr√≠guez

articles.title: Popover API 101
articles.description: Covers the basics of the now well supported Popover API, including a straightforward look at using it, styling it, and animating it.
articles.author: Amit Merchant

articles.title: Floating UI: Positioning for Tooltips, Popovers, Dropdowns, etc.
articles.description: If this reminds you of Tippy.js or Popper at all, it‚Äôs similar and shares a creator and contributor respectively who says it‚Äôs ‚Äúdesigned to be a next-generation evolution‚Äù. Lots of good demos on the homepage, and solid documentation too.
articles.author: atomiks

articles.title: Astro 4.12: üèùÔ∏è Say Hello to Server Islands
articles.description: The latest version of the popular Astro framework includes a new concept of server islands ‚Äî a way to integrate static HTML and server-side generated components together.
articles.author: Erika and Phillips (Astro)

articles.title: Perfect Bug Reporting: A Checklist to Write Bug Reports That Developers Love
articles.description: A nicely-designed interactive site that describes seven steps to help everyone write better bug reports. Might be useful for team members who aren‚Äôt accustomed to reporting bugs.
articles.author: marker.io

articles.title: SENDUNE Designer: An Open-Source Drag-and-Drop HTML Email Builder
articles.description: You can install it locally or try the demo online. Includes three options: The drag-and-drop editor, raw HTML, or plain text. Also allows you to send a test email to yourself, among other features.
articles.author: SENDUNE

articles.title: TargetJ: A UI Framework Designed to Simplify Development and¬†Animation
articles.description: The framework is based on the concept of ‚Äòtargets‚Äô, which form building blocks for components, and are used for animation, loading data, events, etc. There‚Äôs a helpful visual explainer on the home page.
articles.author: livetrails
